descriptions: Student does not demonstrate an understanding of how to represent rational numbers on a number line.
Student struggles to place rational numbers on a number line; placements are often incorrect or illogical.
Student can place integers on a number line, but struggles with fractions or decimals, or the negative signs.
Student can accurately place positive and negative integers, fractions, and decimals on a number line, but struggles with more complex numbers.
Student accurately represents most rational numbers on a number line and can generally explain their placement.
Student flawlessly represents rational numbers on a number line and explains their placement with clarity and precision.
Student cannot interpret inequality statements or relate them to the position of numbers on a number line.
Student struggles to understand the meaning of inequality symbols (>, <, =).
Student can identify the larger or smaller number in a simple inequality but does not connect it to the number line.
Student can relate simple inequality statements to the relative position of numbers on a number line with some errors.
Student accurately interprets inequality statements and connects them to the position of numbers on a number line.
Student demonstrates a deep understanding of inequality statements and can fluently explain the relationship between the symbols and the number line, including complex scenarios.
Student can only order integers. They do not understand how to order decimals or fractions.
Student can order positive rational numbers. Struggles ordering with negative signs.
Student can order most rational numbers, but makes some errors with negative numbers, fractions, or decimals.
Student accurately orders rational numbers with minimal errors. Numbers can be in any form.
Student accurately orders any rational numbers, regardless of sign or form.
